source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Look, here comes the fool.
target: Here comes the fool, i' faith.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But sir, there is no such house, no such maid, and no such men as you have dreamed up, like a certain Stephen Sly and one old John Naps of Greece, a Peter Turph, one “Henry Pimpernell,” and twenty more men of this sort—who never actually existed.
target: Why, sir, you know no house nor no such maid, Nor no such men as you have reckoned up, As Stephen Sly and old John Naps of Greece, And Peter Turph and Henry Pimpernell, And twenty more such names and men as these, Which never were, nor no man ever saw.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish night would come, like a widow dressed in black, so I can learn how to submit to my husband and lose my virginity.
target: Come, civil night, Thou sober-suited matron, all in black, And learn me how to lose a winning match Played for a pair of stainless maidenhoods.

target: When our actions do not, Our fears do make us traitors.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: His majesty is so concerned about my personal safety that he has ordered them to conduct me to the  You’re being arrested?
target: His majesty, Tend'ring my person’s safety, hath appointed This conduct to convey me to the Tower.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I hate it when I hear a blustery actor in a wig tear a passion to shreds, bursting everyone’s eardrums so as to impress the audience on the lower levels of the playhouse, who for the most part can only appreciate loud noises and pantomime shows.
target: Oh, it offends me to the soul to hear a robustious periwig-pated fellow tear a passion to tatters, to very rags, to split the ears of the groundlings, who for the most part are capable of nothing but inexplicable dumb-shows and noise.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well then, leave them alone until they’re sober.
target: Why, then, let them alone till they are sober.

target: Sitting on a bank, Weeping again the king my father’s wrack, This music crept by me upon the waters, Allaying both their fury and my passion With its sweet air.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: it pleases you, I’ll meet you in the marketplace at five and will keep you company until bedtime.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I will find the time to cry for you, Cassius, I’ll find the time.
target: I shall find time, Cassius, I shall find time.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why do you spit at me?
target: Why dost thou spit at me?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What shall I do for you?
target: What shall I do?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Bridegroom?
target: A bridegroom, say you?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give me a goblet.—Hamlet, this pearl’s yours.
target: Stay, give me drink.—Hamlet, this pearl is thine.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your parents are lucky to have such a lovely child.
target: Happy the parents of so fair a child.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Listen to my excuse.
target: Hear my excuse.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is Cinna.
target: This, Cinna.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Dress me up in motley.
target: Invest me in my motley.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Nothing, Messala.
target: Nothing, Messala.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When you ask for my blessing, I’ll get down on my knees and ask you to forgive me.
target: When thou dost ask me blessing, I’ll kneel down And ask of thee forgiveness.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Captain, I have a favor to beg of you.
target: Captain, I thee beseech to do me favors.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There’s certainly not a boy left alive, and it was done by the cowardly rascals who were running from the battle.
target: Tis certain there’s not a boy left alive, and the cowardly rascals that ran from the battle ha' done this slaughter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is Antonio here?
target: What, is Antonio here?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re right—I’ll go quietly.
target: You have prevailed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They certainly will.
target: Yes, by Saint Anne, and ginger shall be hot i' the mouth too.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The French have reinforced their scattered men.
target: The French have reinforced their scattered men.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You insolent rascal, what trade?
target: Thou naughty knave, what trade?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The armies were like two exhausted swimmers clinging to each other and struggling in the water, unable to move.
target: Doubtful it stood, As two spent swimmers that do cling together And choke their art.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Mine wasn’t wearing a bridle.
target: Mine was not bridled.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Have you forgotten all the talks we’ve had together, the vows we made to be like sisters to one another, all the hours we spent together, wishing that we never had to say goodbye—have you forgotten?
target: Is all the counsel that we two have shared, The sisters' vows, the hours that we have spent When we have chid the hasty-footed time For parting us—oh, is it all forgot?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, I’m very scared something awful has happened.
target: Oh, much I fear some ill unthrifty thing.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They’ll tell all.
target: They’ll tell all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Nor is it up to you, my lord.
target: Nor in thine, lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Don’t look so sour.
target: You must not look so sour.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, well, let’s go.
target: Well, well, away.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good grief, do you think that just because I’m dressed like a man, I have a man’s patience?
target: Good my complexion, dost thou think though I am caparisoned like a man, I have a doublet and hose in my disposition?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I am the son of Marcus Cato!
target: I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But excuse me,  Yes, I’m talking about Launcelot, sir.
target: But I pray you, ergo, old man, ergo, I beseech you, talk you of young Master Launcelot?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’d be angry with you if the occasion allowed.
target: I should be angry with you if the time were convenient.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My lady Olivia’s inside, sir.
target: My lady is within, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’d write sad songs about unrequited love and sing them loudly in the middle of the night.
target: Write loyal cantons of contemned love And sing them loud even in the dead of night.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He can’t bear his grief and so he’s losing his mind.
target: All the power of his wits have given way to his impatience.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where’s the passage of holy scripture that you’re basing your sermon on?
target: Where lies your text?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come on, I’ll take you, but honestly I’m only doing it out of pity.
target: Come, I will have thee, but, by this light, I take thee for pity.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Mighty duke, please allow me to say something.
target: Most mighty duke, vouchsafe me speak a word.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, say it, and mean it!
target: Oh, say so, and so be!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What a man!—especially compared to my husband.
target: Oh, the difference of man and man!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Bassanio, the best thing you can do is to keep living and write an epitaph for my gravestone.
target: You cannot better be employed, Bassanio, Than to live still and write mine epitaph.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s enough.
target: Come, go along.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell me where you’ve stowed away my money, or I swear I’ll break that comical head of yours for goofing when I’m not in the mood.
target: Now, as I am a Christian, answer me In what safe place you have bestowed my money, Or I shall break that merry sconce of yours That stands on tricks when I am undisposed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s good for your fresh wound and your bloody noggin.
target: It is good for your green wound and your ploody coxcomb.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I would rather be a country serving maid than a great queen if it meant I could escape your scorn and constant harassment.
target: I had rather be a country servant-maid Than a great queen with this condition, To be so baited, scorned, and stormèd at.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: See, the snail already has its horns, which prevents nasty rumors from spreading about his wife’s infidelity.
target: But he comes armed in his fortune and prevents the slander of his wife.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You lie.
target: Thou liest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: With the help of the grim  The first to greet me there was my great
target: The first that there did greet my stranger-soul Was my great father-in-law, renownèd Warwick, Who spake aloud, “What scourge for perjury Can this dark monarchy afford false Clarence?” And so he vanished.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So let’s see it.
target: And we will hear it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is all that’s left for me to do, but I won’t do it.
target: Yet this I will not do, do how I can.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If people take what he says, fine.
target: An they will take it, so.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Listen up, you slave.
target: Do you hear, you minion?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’ll just turn it into a joke and torment the poor woman even more.
target: He would make but a sport of it and torment the poor lady worse.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re talking about killing?
target: Talk you of killing?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re right, that’s how it is.
target: And so it is.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He had a thousand noses and twisted horns, like wave crests in a storm at sea.
target: He had a thousand noses, Horns whelked and waved like the enragèd sea.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Bring ink and paper, Charmian.
target: Ink and paper, Charmian.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What are you going to do for her?
target: What wilt thou do for her?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m not sad, my lord.
target: Not sad, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: As long as you move gracefully, look handsome, and say nothing, I’m yours for the dance.
target: So you walk softly, and look sweetly, and say nothing, I am yours for the walk, and especially when I walk away.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I don’t know.
target: I cannot tell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Excuse me?
target: My lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I have no power over you.
target: I have no power upon you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I didn’t, my lord.
target: Not I, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I know that my lady’s going to end up hitting him.
target: I know my lady will strike him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I won’t move to please anybody.
target: I will not budge for no man’s pleasure, I.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I know where she is and, if you don’t mind, I will set her before you tomorrow, whole and unharmed.
target: I know into what straits of fortune she is driven, and it is not impossible to me, if it appear not inconvenient to you, to set her before your eyes tomorrow, human as she is, and without any danger.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You couldn’t see him, but I could.
target: That very time I saw (but thou couldst not) Flying between the cold moon and the Earth, Cupid all armed.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here comes my lady.
target: Here comes my lady.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good night to you.
target: Speak to her, Hamlet.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Let’s not argue here in front of both our armies, which ought to see nothing but love between us.
target: Before the eyes of both our armies here, Which should perceive nothing but love from us, Let us not wrangle.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Get me some poison tonight, Iago.
target: Get me some poison, Iago, this night.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes.
target: Yes.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What, my lord?
target: What, my lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No.
target: Why, no.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, indeed, it was, and he pushed it away three times, each time more gently than the last; and at each refusal my countrymen shouted.
target: Ay, marry, was ’t, and he put it by thrice, every time gentler than other, and at every putting-by mine honest neighbors shouted.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Messala, today is my birthday—I was born on this very day.
target: Messala, This is my birthday, as this very day Was Cassius born.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now is the time when we need your help.
target: Now is the time of help.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’re a natural-born philosopher!
target: Such a one is a natural philosopher.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That will be a good thing.
target: That is some good.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where is kind Hastings?
target: Where is kind Hastings?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh Friar, damned souls use the word banishment to describe hell.
target: O Friar, the damnèd use that word in hell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A greater power than we can fight has ruined our plan.
target: A greater power than we can contradict Hath thwarted our intents.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Caesar.
target: Caesar’s.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sheep pens are empty in the middle of the flooded fields, and the crows get fat from eating the dead bodies of infected sheep.
target: The fold stands empty in the drownèd field, And crows are fatted with the murrain flock.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Still, Edmund was beloved.
target: Yet Edmund was beloved.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But give words a chance.
target: Why should calamity be full of words?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But as a gentleman and a soldier he’s promised me he won’t hurt you.
target: But he has promised me, as he is a gentleman and a soldier, he will not hurt you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then please, put off your eating for a little while I, like a mother doe, find my fawn and bring it food.
target: Then but forbear your food a little while Whiles, like a doe, I go to find my fawn And give it food.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: God forbid that I should prevent sacred devotion!
target: God shield I should disturb devotion!— Juliet, on Thursday early will I rouse ye.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s rushing on his way here right now, and Regan’s with him.
target: He’s coming hither—now, i' th' night, i' th' haste, And Regan with him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’ve never seen anything like it.
target: You have not seen such a thing as ’tis.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Since it’s drizzling, stand under this overhang with me and, like a true drunk, I’ll tell you everything.
target: Stand thee close, then, under this penthouse, for it drizzles rain, and I will, like a true drunkard, utter all to thee.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go get money.
target: Traverse, go, provide thy money.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And even though Nature has given us the wit to have this argument, hasn’t Fortune sent this fool here to stop us?
target: Though Nature hath given us wit to flout at Fortune, hath not Fortune sent in this fool to cut off the argument?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: All right, stop this.
target: Pray you, no more of this.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Can you do that?
target: Can you do it?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do what he says, William.
target: Do, good William.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She’s too beautiful and too wise to deserve heaven’s blessing by making me despair.
target: She is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair, To merit bliss by making me despair.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your head is as full of fights as an egg is full of yolk, but your head has been beaten like scrambled eggs from so much fighting.
target: Thy head is as full of quarrels as an egg is full of meat, and yet thy head hath been beaten as addle as an egg for quarreling.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Think about that, and about what followed afterward.
target: Mark his condition and the event.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll kill him!
target: He dies!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It takes a good priest to practice what he preaches.
target: It is a good divine that follows his own instructions.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A sense of security opens the door to conspiracy.
target: Security gives way to conspiracy.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: God protect you from them and from other false friends!
target: God keep you from them, and from such false friends.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The court has sent for us.
target: Marry, we were sent for to the justices.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh wise judge!
target: O wise and upright judge!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here it is.
target: There’s another.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now, we go contentedly to freedom—not banishment.
target: Now go we in content To liberty, and not to banishment.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll never believe any of these old legends or fairy tales.
target: I never may believe These antique fables nor these fairy toys.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Wait, Petruchio, I should go with you.
target: Tarry, Petruchio, I must go with thee, For in Baptista’s keep my treasure is.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then I’ll really give it to you.
target: I will then give it you soundly.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, this is what love does.
target: Why, such is love’s transgression.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: In that case, there’s reason to hope a man’s memory may outlive him by six months.
target: Then there’s hope a great man’s memory may outlive his life half a year.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir, you need a drink.
target: O knight, thou lackest a cup of canary.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go back to where you’re staying and go to sleep.
target: Retire thee, go where thou art billeted.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now all is for nothing.
target: All’s but naught.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Is he crazy with love for you?
target: Mad for thy love?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s not safe to be straightforward and honest.
target: Take note, take note, O world, To be direct and honest is not safe.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m very glad to see you.
target: I am very glad to see you.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Play the kind of music that puts people to sleep.
target: Music such as charmeth sleep!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There must be some mistake, sir.
target: You mistake, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But our courage should only be the greater for that.
target: The greater therefore should our courage be.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: On a night like this!
target: In such a night as this!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go ahead.
target: Go thou.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: One smile from him would repair my decayed beauty.
target: My decayèd fair A sunny look of his would soon repair.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Captain Jamy is a wonderfully valorous gentleman, that’s certain, one with great learning and knowledge concerning ancient warfare, I happen to know from his maneuvers.
target: Captain Jamy is a marvelous falorous gentleman, that is certain, and of great expedition and knowledge in th' aunchient wars, upon my particular knowledge of his directions.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Have your wife attend to her, and bring them along as soon as you can.
target: I prithee, let thy wife attend on her, And bring them after in the best advantage.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And you won’t tell me who you are?
target: Nor will you not tell me who you are?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The great emperor Caesar, dead and turned to clay, might plug up a hole to keep the wind away.
target: Imperious Caesar, dead and turned to clay, Might stop a hole to keep the wind away.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where will we meet in the morning?
target: Where shall we meet i' th' morning?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lucentio!
target: Lucentio!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You thought about it too long, considering what you found there.
target: Too long a pause for that which you find there.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But aren’t you drowned, Stephano?
target: But art thou not drowned, Stephano?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Congratulations, lady: you resemble a most honorable man.
target: Truly, the lady fathers herself.—Be happy, lady, for you are like an honorable father.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He must be very near by now.
target: He is very near by this.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So what’s going on?
target: How now?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If you have a voice or can make sounds, speak to me.
target: If thou hast any sound or use of voice, Speak to me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go tell the hunters to blow their horns and wake them up.
target: Go, bid the huntsmen wake them with their horns.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I pity England, but not myself.
target: Woe, woe for England!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Here.
target: Here.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, no, the bell.
target: No, no, the bell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Who are they following?
target: This doth betoken The corse they follow did with desperate hand Fordo its own life.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve heard that the pyramids build by the Ptolemies are splendid.
target: Nay, certainly, I have heard the Ptolemies’ pyramises are very goodly things.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The devil’s after me!
target: The foul fiend follows me!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I could even supply the dialogue between you and your lover if you did your little puppet show of love for me.
target: I could interpret between you and your love, if I could see the puppets dallying.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please, if you can do it without taking advantage of the young man, buy the cottage, pasture, and flock for us, and we’ll pay you for it.
target: I pray thee, if it stand with honesty, Buy thou the cottage, pasture, and the flock, And thou shalt have to pay for it of us.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: How many times will Caesar bleed again in show, though he now lies at the base of Pompey’s statue, as worthless as dust!
target: How many times shall Caesar bleed in sport, That now on Pompey’s basis lies along No worthier than the dust!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, Fate, come and cut the thread of my life.
target: O Fates, come, come, Cut thread and thrum.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Good Captain Blunt, tell the earl goodnight from me, and tell him that by two in the morning I would like him to visit my tent.
target: The earl of Pembroke keeps his regiment— Good Captain Blunt, bear my goodnight to him, And by the second hour in the morning Desire the earl to see me in my tent.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Have some patience, please.
target: Have patience, I beseech.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Stay here for a moment.
target: Stay but a little.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do you want?
target: What do you here?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A grave?
target: A grave?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll follow you, my lord.
target: I’ll wait upon your Lordship.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, dear!
target: Alas!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The wind that scatters young men throughout the world, encouraging them to seek their fortunes some place other than home, where there’s little to be found in the way of experience.
target: Such wind as scatters young men through the world To seek their fortunes farther than at home, Where small experience grows.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Wait, Tybalt, wait!
target: Stay, Tybalt, stay!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What can I do for your highness?
target: What’s your highness’ pleasure?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is good.
target: This is well.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: For now, don’t try to persuade me anymore—I ask you as a friend.
target: For this present, I would not, so with love I might entreat you, Be any further moved.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do this immediately, and send him packing.
target: Do this expediently, and turn him going.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lovely Beatrice, I thank you for taking the pains to tell me that.
target: Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Can we finish our lunch?
target: We’ll mend our dinner here.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What?
target: How now?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I didn’t, either.
target: sits.—I did never think that lady would have loved any man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: A very clear way, but there is no friend who will undertake it.
target: A very even way, but no such friend.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The hand of death has taken him.
target: The hand of death hath raught him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: When you find out who started this disagreement, turn your anger upon them.
target: When it appears to you where this begins, Turn your displeasure that way, for our faults Can never be so equal that your love Can equally move with them.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well said!
target: Spoke like an officer!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If we were in front of our armies, about to fight, I would do this.
target: Were we before our armies, and to fight, I should do thus.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hey, if I’d remembered something about him, I could have had a good comeback for my uncle, touching on his growth worse than he touched on mine.
target: Now, by my troth, if I had been remembered, I could have given my uncle’s grace a flout To touch his growth nearer than he touched mine.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come here.
target: Come, bird, come.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s true.
target: It is too true an evil.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m coming, I’m coming!
target: Anon, anon!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’ll discover that his youthful follies were like the persona that  Well, you’re wrong, my Lord High Constable.
target: Well, ’tis not so, my Lord High Constable.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, that devious Egyptian spirit!
target: Oh, this false soul of Egypt!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll only admit that you’re sane when you agree with Pythagoras and hesitate to kill a bird because it might contain your grandmother’s soul.
target: Thou shalt hold the opinion of Pythagoras ere I will allow of thy wits, and fear to kill a woodcock lest thou dispossess the soul of thy grandam.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: In your own kitchens you act like wildcats.
target: You are pictures out of door, bells in your parlors, wild-cats in your kitchens, saints in your injuries, devils being offended, players in your housewifery, and housewives in your beds.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s the obvious conclusion from that?
target: What should I think on ’t?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Lay off, already!
target: Quiet thy cudgel.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Only God knows when we’ll meet again.
target: Farewell!—God knows when we shall meet again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: No, not too upset.
target: No, not much moved.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Get up from your beds as if you were rising out of your own graves, and walk like ghosts to come witness this horror.
target: As from your graves rise up, and walk like sprites, To countenance this horror!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tell me so I can be satisfied.
target: Let me be satisfied.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Do you know them?
target: Do you know them?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Tut, tut, you’ve become rather icy.
target: Tut, tut, thou art all ice; thy kindness freezes.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Goodbye.
target: Farewell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Banquo and Donalbain, Malcolm!
target: Banquo and Donalbain!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.
target: I’ll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Get away from me, you ass!
target: Away!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The servants of the Duke and my lieutenant?
target: The servants of the Duke and my lieutenant?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I ask too much of you, but you’re always willing.
target: I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s true—if the devil’s judging her.
target: That’s certain—if the devil may be her judge.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s a green-eyed monster that makes fun of the victims it devours.
target: It is the green-eyed monster which doth mock The meat it feeds on.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The crows flying down below look as small as ants.
target: The crows and choughs that wing the midway air Show scarce so gross as beetles.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I won’t.
target: I will not.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Horny animals!
target: Goats and monkeys!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m glad about that.
target: I thank it.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, cut my bodice-staps so that my pent-up heart can have some room to breathe, or I’ll faint from this deadly news!
target: Ah, cut my lace asunder, That my pent heart may have some scope to beat, Or else I swoon with this dead-killing news!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Go to him from me.
target: Go you to him from me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You did—not just once or twice, but twenty times.
target: Not once, nor twice, but twenty times you have.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We’ll drive them to a
target: Here’s that shall drive some of them to a noncome.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So let me hear what you have to say.
target: So, let me hear you speak.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They say that this town is full of deception—illusionists that can fool the eye, dark sorcerers who can bewitch your mind, soul-killing witches who can disfigure your body, disguised swindlers, fast-talking fakers, and all kinds of other unchecked sins.
target: They say this town is full of cozenage, As nimble jugglers that deceive the eye, Dark-working sorcerers that change the mind, Soul-killing witches that deform the body, Disguised cheaters, prating mountebanks, And many suchlike liberties of sin.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This is the end of my journey, the end of my life.
target: Here is my journey’s end, here is my butt, And very sea-mark of my utmost sail.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We only drink toasts to my niece.
target: With drinking healths to my niece.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: God be with you all.
target: God be with you all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What did he do that made him flee this land?
target: What had he done to make him fly the land?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I know I’m not fooling myself, or letting myself get carried away by my imagination, because every clue points to the fact that Lady Olivia loves me.
target: I do not now fool myself, to let imagination jade me, for every reason excites to this, that my lady loves me.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve told her father, and he’s given his permission.
target: I have broke with her father and his goodwill obtained.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please forgive me, master.
target: Pardon, master.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why, madam, have I offered you my love only to be flouted in front of the king?
target: Why, madam, have I offered love for this, To be so flouted in this royal presence?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I certainly will, sir.
target: Marry, will I, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hey, Mountain, hey!
target: Hey, Mountain, hey!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Niece, will you take care of those things I mentioned?
target: Niece, will you look to those things I told you of?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It’s too late.
target: It is too late.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish to God that the golden crown that I’ll have to wear were red-hot steel and burned me straight through to the brain!
target: O, would to God that the inclusive verge Of golden metal that must round my brow Were red-hot steel to sear me to the brains!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Come on, I won’t stand for it anymore.
target: Go to, I’ll no more on ’t.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: We want answers.
target: We will be satisfied!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh, Lord, if they were married, they’d drive themselves crazy within a week.
target: O Lord, my lord, if they were but a week married, they would talk themselves mad.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And when I get my reward, I’ll get out of here.
target: And when I have my meed, I will away, For this will out, and then I must not stay.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Watch her.
target: Observe her, stand close.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: It wouldn’t surprise me, my lord.
target: No wonder, my lord.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Angels are still bright even though Lucifer, the brightest angel, fell from heaven.
target: Angels are bright still, though the brightest fell.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Sir Walter Herbert, a renowned soldier; Sir Gilbert Talbot; Sir William Stanley; Oxford; the highly feared Pembroke; Sir James Blunt; Rice ap Thomas, with a valiant crew; and many other famous and powerful noblemen.
target: Sir Walter Herbert, a renownèd soldier; Sir Gilbert Talbot, Sir William Stanley, Oxford, redoubted Pembroke, Sir James Blunt, And Rice ap Thomas, with a valiant crew, And many other of great name and worth; And towards London they do bend their power, If by the way they be not fought withal.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Then you have to say, “I take you, Rosalind, to be my lawfully wedded wife.” I take you, Rosalind, to be my lawfully wedded wife.
target: Then you must say “I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.” I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: This song’s about my dead father.
target: The ditty does remember my drowned father.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: She has betrayed me and shall die.
target: She hath betrayed me and shall die the death.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Are you insane, old man?
target: Why, art thou mad, old fellow?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Liar and slave!
target: Liar and slave!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But I’m overjoyed!
target: Oh, my soul’s joy!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What do kings have that private men do not, besides the pomp of their position?
target: And what have kings that privates have not too, Save ceremony, save general ceremony?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Our masquerade mates are waiting for us.
target: Our masquing mates by this time for us stay.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Amen.
target: Amen.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now Margaret’s curse has fallen on our heads, for standing by and doing nothing when Richard stabbed her son.
target: Now Margaret’s curse is fall'n upon our heads, When she exclaimed on Hastings, you, and I, For standing by when Richard stabbed her son.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Can’t you talk about anything besides ladies?
target: Talkest thou nothing but of ladies?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: But honestly, I should have been a woman.
target: But i' faith, I should have been a woman by right.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He and I will be there.
target: That you shall surely find him, Lead to the Sagittary the raisèd search, And there will I be with him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I know that young men look forward to their rest.
target: I know young bloods look for a time of rest.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Summertime in Verona has no flower as fine as him.
target: Verona’s summer hath not such a flower.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’ve said nothing wrong.
target: I speak no treason.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Prison, my lord?
target: Prison, my lord?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well then, he’s God’s soldier now!
target: Why then, God’s soldier be he!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If she offers him her love, it’s very possible that he’ll scorn it, since, as we all know, he tends to be contemptuous.
target: If she should make tender of her love, ’tis very possible he’ll scorn it, for the man, as you know all, hath a contemptible spirit.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Dat it not be de custom pour les ladies of France—I cannot tell vat is  To kiss.
target: Dat it is not be de fashion pour les ladies of France—I cannot tell wat is  To kiss.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He answered, “You penniless bastard!
target: He replied, “Thou unpossessing bastard!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Everyone who comes to gamble on winning me has to swear to these three rules.
target: To these injunctions every one doth swear That comes to hazard for my worthless self.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: There’d be no marriage?
target: No marrying ’mong his subjects?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: His son was a minor only two years ago.
target: His son was but a ward two years ago.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My name is Mary, sir.
target: My name is Mary, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Why?
target: Upon what cause?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Hurry to a convent.
target: Go thy ways to a nunnery.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Pray, let me stay.
target: Please, let me stay.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Take your penalty.
target: Take thy forfeiture.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give me my sin back.
target: Give me my sin again.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: May the gods destroy you!
target: The gods confound thee!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If what you say is true, you can do the same to me.
target: If thy speech be sooth, I care not if thou dost for me as much.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: If the Jew cuts deep enough, I’ll pay it instantly with all my heart.
target: For if the Jew do cut but deep enough, I’ll pay it presently with all my heart.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He’s not the most polite man in the world, but, believe me, he’s gentle as a lamb.
target: He is not the flower of courtesy, but, I’ll warrant him, as gentle as a lamb.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Those trumpets are calling us in to dinner.
target: Hark, how these instruments summon to supper.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He cut my head and gave Sir Toby a bloody head, too.
target: He has broke my head across and has given Sir Toby a bloody coxcomb too.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Dear father, if you caused this terrible storm with your magic powers, please put an end to it.
target: If by your art, my dearest father, you have Put the wild waters in this roar, allay them.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Will we hear from you before bedtime, Catesby?
target: Shall we hear from you, Catesby, ere we sleep?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Now get out of here!
target: Hence!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The cold wind’s still blowing through the hawthorn tree.
target: Still through the hawthorn blows the cold wind, says, “Suum, mun, nonny.” Dauphin my boy, my boy, cessez.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: May God keep you well, sir.
target: God save you, sir.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: All of us have reason to mourn the dimming of our shining star the king.
target: All of us have cause To wail the dimming of our shining star, But none can help our harms by wailing them.— Madam, my mother, I do cry you mercy; I did not see your Grace.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Yes, I’ll wipe my mind clean of all trivial facts and memories and preserve only your commandment there.
target: Yea, from the table of my memory I’ll wipe away all trivial fond records, All saws of books, all forms, all pressures past That youth and observation copied there, And thy commandment all alone shall live Within the book and volume of my brain, Unmixed with baser matter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Watch Titinius and tell me what you see in the field.
target: Regard Titinius, And tell me what thou notest about the field.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Friendship is enduring except when love is involved.
target: Friendship is constant in all other things Save in the office and affairs of love.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: They plan to spend the night in Sardis.
target: They mean this night in Sardis to be quartered.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The day will come when you’ll wish I could help you cast spells against this poisonous, hunchbacked toad.
target: The day will come that thou shalt wish for me To help thee curse that poisonous bunch-backed toad.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Well, hello there, Horatio!
target: What ho, Horatio!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Where could I have lost that handkerchief, Emilia?
target: Where should I lose that handkerchief, Emilia?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Niece, you are exceptionally perceptive.
target: Cousin, you apprehend passing shrewdly.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: What’s wrong, cousin?
target: Why, how now, cousin!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: And though his feelings may be pitched higher than ours, when they plummet, they plummet that much farther.
target: His ceremonies laid by, in his nakedness he appears but a man, and though his affections are higher mounted than ours, yet when they stoop, they stoop with the like wing.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: My heart is ten times lighter than my looks.
target: My heart is ten times lighter than my looks.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: From a certain knight who swore on his honor that the pancakes he was eating were good, and that the mustard on top of them—he swore on his honor—was bad.
target: Of a certain knight that swore by his honor they were good pancakes, and swore by his honor the mustard was naught.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Your case is better than that.
target: Your case is better.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: You’ll know about that later.
target: That shall you know hereafter.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I know him.
target: I know the man.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I’m in so much trouble with my niece that it wouldn’t be safe to let this prank go to its conclusion.
target: If he may be conveniently delivered, I would he were, for I am now so far in offense with my niece that I cannot pursue with any safety this sport to the upshot.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: So, without further ado, the best thing to do now is probably just to shake hands and go our separate ways.
target: And so, without more circumstance at all, I hold it fit that we shake hands and part.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The work we enjoy is not really work.
target: The labor we delight in physics pain.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: The king is coming here tonight.
target: The king comes here tonight.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: That’s a sin young men often commit because they allow their eyes to wander.
target: Hath not else his eye Stray’d his affection in unlawful love, A sin prevailing much in youthful men Who give their eyes the liberty of gazing?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Please grant my prayer so my faith doesn’t turn to despair.
target: They pray; grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: I wish you could just stammer this hidden man out of your mouth like wine out of a narrow-necked bottle: either too much at once or none at all.
target: I would thou couldst stammer, that thou might’st pour this concealed man out of thy mouth as wine comes out of a narrow-mouthed bottle—either too much at once, or none at all.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Oh bloody Richard!
target: O bloody Richard!

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Welcome, welcome to all of you.
target: You are welcome, masters, welcome, all!—I am glad to see thee well.—Welcome, good friends.—O old friend?

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: He looks like he just recently stopped breastfeeding.
target: One would think his mother’s milk were scarce out of him.

source: Rewrite in Shakespearean style: Give me Bianca for my inheritance.
target: Give me Bianca for my patrimony.
